items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 established the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $87,800 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of December 10, 2015 through January 9, 2016 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Short-Term Hourly, Substitute, Professional Expert & Athletic Support Services, Student Assistant and Volunteer personnel actions as submitted.

items.item_details:
In September 2015, the solicitation for food and vending services proposal was issued to ten potential vendors identified by surveying other bay area community colleges and from vendors currently on the District's list of potential vendors.  Of the ten vendors, two submitted bids to the District.  The respondents were Fresh and Natural Food Group and WM CafĂŠ.
	 
The two bids were evaluated by a committee comprised of staff from the District's Fiscal Services Office, the Campuses' Business Service Office, and San Jose City College's Student Services Area.  Both respondents provided a presentation to the committee and were evaluated based upon the following criteria:  Operations Experience (20%); Food Service Menu, which included ethnic diversity, quality, freshness, and nutrition (35%); Personnel Profile (5%); Commissions and Scholarships (10%); References (10%); Vending Machine Proposal (5%); Financial Responsibility (5%); and Small Business (10%).
	 
Based upon this evaluation, the committee is unanimously recommending that the Board of Trustees award the food and vending service contract to Fresh and Natural Food Group.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve and award the contract for food and vending services to Fresh and Natural Food Service Group for a period of three (3) years, subject to satisfactory performance, with two optional one-year extensions for a total contract term not to exceed five (5) years.
items.item_text: Award of Food and Vending Services Contract
items.item_text_raw: 8. Award of Food and Vending Services Contract

items.item_details:
A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve out of state travel for students: Tempest Franklin, Zainab Yusuf, Brittany Hayes, Kayla Jones, Donald Walker, Selamawit Mulat, Misiker Negash, Rita Russom, Tasean Clark, and Bobbie Brown to tour Historically Black College & Universities (HBCU).  The students will be accompanied by San Jose City College faculty members Meiko Daire and Rachel Hagen.
	 
The students and faculty will leave on March 27, 2016 and return April 1, 2016.  Students will visit:  Dillard University, Xavier University, Alabama State, Tuskegee University, Clark-Atlanta University, Spelman or Morehouse College, Stillman College, and Fisk University. The cost for travel is $19,688.00 and will be covered using Student Equity Funds.
	 
The primary objective of this tour is to expose SJCC students to the benefit of attending HBCUs. The HBCU tour is one of the strategies and activities identified in the SJCC Student Equity Plan to increase âTransfer Ratesâ among Black and African American students. Students that participate in the HBCU tour will also receive assistance with the HBCU admissions process.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve San Jose City College students and faculty out of state travel and waive BP 4300 per Title 5, section 55220.
items.item_text: Students Out-of-State Travel: Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, and Louisiana
items.item_text_raw: 9. Students Out-of-State Travel: Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, and Louisiana

items.item_details: The District entered into a Lease Agreement with the South Bay Regional Public Safety Center on July 1, 2013 for real property and improvements at 3095 Yerba Buena Road, San Jose, Santa Clara County. The Lease Term and prior extension is set to expire on June 30, 2016. The District and SBRPSTC desire to extend the Term of the Lease to February 28, 2017. This period is to be referred to as the"Third Extension Term". Rental Payments for the period between July 1, 2016 and February 28, 2017 shall be Twenty Thousand Eight Hundred Thirty Four dollars ($20,834.00) per month.  All other provisions of the original Lease shall apply.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to extend the current real property and improvements lease with the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium, a California Joint Powers Agency through February 28, 2017.
items.item_text: Extension of Lease of Premises to the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium, a California Joint Powers Agency.
items.item_text_raw: 10. Extension of Lease of Premises to the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium, a California Joint Powers Agency.

items.item_details:
The SJCC International Student Program is requesting Board approval to participate in the 2nd overseas travel recruitment to Asia to increase international student enrollment as it will benefit our campus and District, both educationally and culturally.  For the past few decades, San Jose City College (SJCC) has successfully accommodated international students in our comprehensive one-stop program.  With the growing trend to attract students to study at community colleges in the U.S., SJCC has the goal of becoming one of the premier institutions for international students in the Bay Area. Staff attending will be: Doriann Tran, SJCC International Counselor/Coordinator. Proposed dates for out of country student recruitment activities are (2/24/2016 Departure– 3/14/2016 Return). Cities where recruitment will occur include: 2/27 Singapore, 2/29 Kuala Lumpur, and 3/8 Manila. SJCC recruitment efforts will include: agent/student/parent exhibitions, school visits and presentations.                   Recruitment and fair participation is the most viable option for San Jose 
City College to continue to gain visibility and credibility as the college is entering the recruitment arena for the first year.  San Jose City College has selected to participate in the Asia recruitment events offered through AEO and COMPASS due to their reputation and the high demand in Asia to study in the United States.  AEO has operated student recruitment tours in Asia for 30 years, providing recruitment events such as college student fairs and visits to local schools.  COMPASS is an approved member of the British Council Education Network and has successfully sent many students to study abroad due to its in-country location.
 
Our location in Silicon Valley offers a unique opportunity to brand our college overseas as a gateway to Silicon Valley and the Bay Area; as well as provide our students with an opportunity to study with and interact with students from around the world.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve International Student Recruitment Travel for Spring 2016.

items.item_details:
On August 25, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Rodan Builders in the amount of $960,000 to provide construction services for the Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.
Change Order No. 002 includes work that is the result of costs from the addition of supports for the electrical transformer frame, demolition of existing wire-mold not required, the addition of a furred out-wall to protect HVAC piping and the addition of a 100 amp breaker at panel H2 to feed transformer T-L1. The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                             $960,000.00
Previous Approved Changes                                        $  12,486.60
Change Order No. 002                                                  $    8,381.49
Total Contract and Changes                                         $980,868.09
	 
The net change to Rodan Builders’ contract as a result of all changes issued is $20,868.09 which equates to 2.20% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 in the amount of $8,381.49 to Rodan Builders, Inc. for the Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 – Rodan Builders, Inc. Change Order No. 002
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 – Rodan Builders, Inc. Change Order No. 002

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Change Order No. 013 includes Work that is the result of costs and credits from:  addition of the aluminum back-pan for classroom storefront areas, revision of power and data locations within the Deans’ Offices and the addition of Liquid-Crystal Display (LCD) Panels and accessories for the turnkey system in Building B.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                             $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes                                        $     406,152.00
Change Order No. 013                                                 $       38,043.00
Total Contract and Changes                                         $42,083,924.00
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $444,195.00 which equates to 1.10% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 013 in the amount of $38,043.00 to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On June 10, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved the budget for the New Gym Sitework and Auxiliary Buildings Project at SJCC.
	 
Following a request for Qualifications issued by the District, Artik Art & Architecture  was awarded a Master Agreement by the Board of Trustees on May 24, 2012. 
	 
PAA #SJCC-05 is for Artik Art & Architecture to provide the Design Consultant Services on the Concessions/Team Room and Visiting Team Room modular buildings. Pricing was received from LPAS and based on the review of their rates; Artik Art & Architecture was determined to be the best value to the District.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) or SJCC-005 in the amount of $125,400 to Artik Art & Architecture , for New Gym Sitework & Auxiliary Buildings Project #31125 - Concessions/Team Room and Visiting Team Room Design Services.

items.item_details:
On April 8, 2014 the Board of Trustees agreed to enter into a contract with LPAS, Inc. for Professional Services which includes Design Development, Construction Documents, DSA Approval, Bid Documents, Contractor Pre-Qualification, Contractor Selection and Bidding, Construction Administration, and Close-Out/Post-Construction/Occupancy in the amount of $1,474,788  for the Physical Education Building  #122 at San Jose City College.
	 
The Owner has revised the project delivery method from Lease Lease-Back to Design Bid Build. Amendment No. 005 includes, additional design services required due to the change of the delivery method.  LPAS, Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for changes that include additional work.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The item in this Amendment results in an addition to the contract of $77,775.
	 
         Original Contract Amount       $1,474,788
         Previous Approved Revisions      118,875
         This Revision #005                        77,775
                 
         Total Contract and Changes    $1,674,438
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Amendment No. 005 to Standard Form of Agreement in the amount of $77,775 to LPAS, Inc., for the Physical Education Building #122 at SJCC.

items.item_details:
The contract for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at San Jose City College (SJCC) included the build-out the west end of the Career Technical Education Building 200 in order to accommodate 20 welding booths for the new ironworkers training program.  Upgrade the building’s electrical and mechanical systems to support the utility requirements, construct an office space to be utilized by the Work Experience Program and construct an additional classroom.
	 
On June 9, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. to perform the Work. On June 16, 2015 construction activity began and on October 30, 2015 major construction activity was completed. As of January 29, 2016 all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received and all change orders have been approved.
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by R.C. Benson & Sons Inc., for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at SJCC.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 – R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. – Notice of Completion (NOC)
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 – R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. – Notice of Completion (NOC)

items.item_details:
The contract for the Utilities Upgrade Phase II Project #31110-2 at San Jose City College (SJCC) included the upgrading of existing & installation of new utility services for SJCC. Phase II of the project consists of the installation of underground infrastructure necessary to support upcoming construction across the campus and will include new water services, electrical, hydronic heating and cooling services
	 
On June 9, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Lewis & Tibbitts Inc. to perform the Work. On June 15, 2015 construction activity began and on November 30, 2015 major construction activity was completed. As of January 29, 2016 all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received and all change orders have been approved.
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by Lewis & Tibbitts Inc., for the Utilities Upgrade Phase II Project #31110-2 at SJCC.

items.item_details: The Board of Trustees adopted the District's operating budget at its meeting of September 8, 2015.  As required by Board Policy 6250 subsequent budget transfers and revisions must be approved by the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the resolution authorizing the budget transfers and revisions of funds within expenditure accounts, authorizing the appropriation of the receipt of unanticipated revenues in certain programs, and authorizing the reversal of appropriations in certain programs due to the non-receipt of program revenues.
items.item_text: Resolution Number 020916-1 Approving District Budget Transfers and Revisions
items.item_text_raw: 1. Resolution Number 020916-1 Approving District Budget Transfers and Revisions

items.item_details: The San Jose Evergreen Community College District joined the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium (SBRPSTC) in 1995; however, over time the District's participation has diminished.  This diminished participation accelerated once the District transitioned into basic aid status.  Additionally the imposition of the Affordable Care Act has created an undue administrative burden and potential financial liability to the District due to the employment of instructional personnel by the District on behalf of the SBRPSTC.  Therefore staff is recommending formal withdrawal from the SBRPSTC effective June 30, 2016.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the resolution authorizing the withdrawal from the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium.
items.item_text: Resolution Number 020916-2 Authorizing the Withdrawal from the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium
items.item_text_raw: 2. Resolution Number 020916-2 Authorizing the Withdrawal from the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium

items.item_details: On January 29, 2016, President Obama issued a Presidential Proclamation proclaiming February 2016 as National African American History Month.  In support of the Proclamation and in celebration of the achievements of African American faculty, administrators, staff and students, Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College organized many events in which African American history and culture are celebrated.  It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 020916-3 in support of February 2016 as Black/African American History Month.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 020916-3 in support of February 2016 as Black/African American History Month.
items.item_text: Resolution No. 020916-3 in Support of February 2016 as Black/African American History Month
items.item_text_raw: 3. Resolution No. 020916-3 in Support of February 2016 as Black/African American History Month

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria were added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  These criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.  In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 20 does not contain substantive changes based on the criteria set forth above.  In this bond list revision request,Evergreen Valley College is transferring budget from C32299:  Campus Contingency – Evergreen to Projects 32702:  IT Infrastructure Improvements and 32703:  Technology Upgrades to accommodate additional budget needs.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 20 dated February 9, 2016.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented.

items.item_text_raw: 4. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Bond List Revision No. 20

items.item_details: The college presidents will provide an accreditation update.
items.item_text: Accreditation Update
items.item_text_raw: 1. Accreditation Update

items.item_details:
Administrative Procedure 6380 stipulates that "The District's goal is to remove any and all barriers to a full and equal opportunity for minority-owned or (women)-owned businesses to provide products and services to the District. No vendor shall be excluded from consideration for, or award of, District purchases on the basis of ethnic group identification, race, color, language, accent, immigration status, ancestry, national origin, age, gender, religion, sexual orientation, transgender, marital status, veteran status, physical or mental disability, or on the basis of these characteristics or association with person or group with one or more of these characteristics.
	 
Based upon input of the Board a the November 10, 2015 meeting, District and Gilbane staff have been working to improve the small and diverse business outreach program. The presentation will be an update to the Board on the steps being considered to improve small and diverse business participation within the District vendor systems. Presentation by District Legal Counsel, Phil Jaret, regarding adopting changes similar to other Community College Districts Small, Local and Diverse Business Program, as well as, information on the possible implementation of the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA).

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
